key_points: Two Iowa teens, Willard Noble Chaiden Miller and Jeremy Everett Goodale, both 16, charged with first-degree murder in the death of high school Spanish teacher Nohema Graber.
Nohema Graber's body was discovered in Fairfield's Chautauqua Park under a tarp, wheelbarrow, and railroad ties.
Graber, 66, had been walking in the park and suffered inflicted trauma to the head.
The suspects will be charged as adults due to the circumstances and their ages.
Fairfield High School canceled classes following the incident, underscoring the community's shock.
Social media activity and a search of the suspects' homes aided the police investigation.
Graber was remembered by the community as a leader, particularly within Fairfield's Latino community, and deeply loving towards her family, students, and friends.
The Fairfield Community School District emphasized the well-being of students and staff as a top priority.
The President of the Iowa State Education Association expressed condolences and highlighted the role of educators in protecting students.
The community expresses deep shock and grief, struggling with the motivations behind the violent act.
spokespersons: Laurie Noll (Superintendent, Fairfield Community School District)
Mike Beranek (President, Iowa State Education Association)
